learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate strong proficiency in the editing, proofreading and formatting-for-publication of academic articles.
Apply the Australian Guide to Legal Citation (AGLC) accurately and consistently, in line with the Journal’s internal policies and style guides.

Demonstrate strong appreciation of academic integrity through rigorous citation checking and verification of sources, and alertness to ethical writing and citation practice. Appropriately recognise, reflect upon, and respond to academic integrity issues as they arise.

Recognise, reflect upon, and appropriately respond to ethical issues that arise in the editing process including conflicts of interest, intellectual property and the role of anonymity and confidentiality in academic publishing.

Produce original legal writing of a standard appropriate for public dissemination, demonstrating originality, insight, high-level research and writing skills, and scholarly engagement with contemporary legal issues and/or scholarship.
Learn and work with autonomy, accountability, professionalism and reliability.

Collaborate effectively within an editorial team under faculty editor supervision, developing professional skills in communication, time-management, ethical decision-making, and peer-feedback in a scholarly publishing environment.

assessments.task_description:
Each student editor shall be required to:

(a) Write and submit a case note on a recent Australian judicial or decision in any area of law that has implications beyond the decision in the case itself; or

(b) Write and submit a book review of a recently published legal book in any area of law.

Use of AI:

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Each student editor will undertake the following four tasks for their assigned articles over the course of the Semester, in addition to further group and editorial tasks:

  1. Ensuring Comprehensive Compliance with the AGLC4 and UQLJ Style Guide
  2. Citation and Quotation Checking
  3. Formatting - Apply the UQLJ’s house style consistently across the manuscript, including headings, footnotes, tables, case names, legislation, and other typographical elements, and prepare the article for publication.
  4. 4. Proofreading - Conduct a thorough line-by-line comprehensive review of finalised manuscripts.
